results.subject: !!!URGENT!!! - HIG Capital
results.description:
Support,

We use an antivirus product from a company called Cylance.

Cylance is quarantining a file from Tanium called mftrcrd.exe.

When we check VirusTotal.com (see link below) we see 3 AV companies that are classifying the file as a possible Trojan

https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/8FDAE311AD59DFBABEC9D1823D24F3E26ADE3213303F2AAAAD037597574D07C0/analysis/

 

c:\program files (x86)\tanium\tanium client\tools\ir\mftrcrd.exe

File Hash

SHA256: 8FDAE311AD59DFBABEC9D1823D24F3E26ADE3213303F2AAAAD037597574D07C0

MD5: 4B59196929CB1EF801C8843685888B9D

 

 

 

Israel Castellanos

Systems Engineering Manager

H.I.G Capital

1450 Brickell Avenue

Suite 3100

Miami, FL 33131

Phone: 305-379-2322

Fax: 305-381-4265

Email: icastellanos@higcapital.com

results.subject: RE: Paris
results.description:
Kevin

It has been a while. I wanted to follow up on this. How can I throttle the uploads?

Luis A. Suarez
Vice President
Information Technology
H.I.G. Capital
1450 Brickell Avenue
Suite 3100
Miami, FL 33131
Phone: 305-379-2322
Fax: 305-381-4202
Email: lsuarez@higcapital.com

From: Kevin Chu [mailto:kevin.chu@tanium.com]
Sent: Wednesday, July 18, 2012 3:25 PM
To: Luis Suarez
Cc: Tanium Support
Subject: Re: Paris

Hi Luis,

Can you take a look at Actions -> Action History to see which actions were deployed around that time? 255M is a sizeable upload and my initial guess is that someone deployed a very large Windows Patch to a machine in Germany.

A couple of optimizations we could make include:
Throttling uploads Taking a look at how your rings are configured so that machines in Germany aren't talking to machines in Paris

Kevin

On Wed, Jul 18, 2012 at 12:18 PM, Luis Suarez < lsuarez@higcapital.com > wrote:

Interesting situation today.

Apparently, the tanium server (based in Miami) was providing an update to a workstation to Germany via Paris and it flooded the network. It actually caused errors on our router.

Luis A. Suarez
Vice President
Information Technology
H.I.G. Capital
1450 Brickell Avenue
Suite 3100
Miami, FL 33131
Phone: 305-379-2322
Fax: 305-381-4202
Email: lsuarez@higcapital.com

From: Lazaro Rivero
Sent: Wednesday, July 18, 2012 3:14 PM
To: Luis Suarez
Cc: Israel Castellanos
Subject: Paris

Luis,

After reviewing the issue with Cisco this mooring in regards to Paris router and the CPU utilization we found that there was a Germany laptop connected to the France server. IP 10.0.50.8, Jens A. laptop. At first I thought it may have been a virus. I initiated a scan but then went to the meeting with Symantec. When I got back I continued to delve into the issue. I am looking at IP Flow from the router and the laptop is still connected to the server.

I identified the task that is using the connection between Paris Server and the Germany laptop to be Tanium. That being said where you running updates at that time of the syslog Orion reports? If so we need to look and open a case with tanium and see why so much data was being sent to just one device instead of small chunks of data.

That large amount of data was causing the router to focus its attention to transferring the data across and dropped processing of other tasks. In this case it started to drop calls.

7/18/2012 10:31 AM

Severity = 3
(0 Emergency - 1 Alert - 2 Critical - 3 Error - 4 Warning - 5 Notice - 6 Informational - 7 Debug)

10.0.40.1 - HIG-FR-PAR-RTR1

>  
> The date range on this one is
> Data Range: 2016-11-11 00:00 2016-12-10
> reference.
>  
> I’d expect this data to all be from external clients to that DMZ zone server simply due to the destination being the external IP address for which the firewall is reporting on. Any transfers from the internal Miami device and the DMZ zone server.  I would have to validate, but I would say I’d see those show up on the IP addresses and internal facing interfaces of the firewall.
>  
> I would have to have the team to run another report since these are not run daily.
>

results.subject: Re: FW: Paris
results.description:
Hi Luis,

Can you take a look at Actions -> Action History to see which actions were
deployed around that time?  255M is a sizeable upload and my initial guess
is that someone deployed a very large Windows Patch to a machine in
Germany.

A couple of optimizations we could make include:

   - Throttling uploads
   - Taking a look at how your rings are configured so that machines in
   Germany aren't talking to machines in Paris


Kevin

results.subject: DELPHI : Installation of ePO agent in Tanium Package ( use template
results.raw_subject: DELPHI : Installation of ePO agent in Tanium Package ( use template
results.description:
Yep - thats a package and should be easy to do. Let me get that on the agenda for items to do.

We would want to do a few things - and - this is where a test lab with either the same or different Tanium server is helpful. If the same we have to be careful of certain things - so something not production is preferred.

The agent is easy - the command installer is easy - if thats all there is to it this should be simple. Is the agent an EXE? I have a template for doing just this and we can walk through it.



Jason Moras
Director of Technical Account Management at Tanium
jason.moras@tanium.com
Office: 248-414-6125
Cell: 248-506-9551

>

> I’m finding units managed by Tanium, that are not running a ePo agent.  I would like to be able to deploy the epo agent when I find such a unit.  The ePo agent is just under 7 meg.  Doable?
>  
> The command for silent install of the agent is  /install=agent /s

results.subject: Pending Validation - Delphi issues with client deployment
results.raw_subject: Pending Validation - Delphi issues with client deployment
results.description:
Tanium clients are not communicating properly to the zone and tanium server. Unsure all details. Opening ticket for Coby and have 4pm meeting to follow up with her.

Plan is to 
1) deploy snapshot tool and receive info to troubleshoot with
2) Get screen shots of tanium server version and tanium zone server versions
3) Verify package status and how it is being pushed ( what servers are in server list )
4) Verify actions to reconfigure are set properly
5) any additional network trouble shooting as required.
